titleStmt.title: Forms VII and VIII IPFV in sound verbs

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for derived of forms VII AND VIII IPFV

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

cit.quote: they rape / they take by force

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "The speech of the Lebanese tribes appears to have been affected considerably by the surrounding sedentary dialects in respect of this feature. For the younger speakers the stress tends to fall on the second syllable: yišt'aġal (he works), etc., whilst amongst older speakers it can fall on the same syllable or on the first: y'ištaġal (he works), etc. The first type is clearly the more sedentary variety (Behnstedt 1997:142-143), and, as was noted above (5.6.2.6.1) the second is more typical of Bedouin dialects." (Pickett 2005: 244).

"The speech of the Lebanese tribes appears to have been affected considerably by the surrounding sedentary dialects in respect of this feature. For the younger speakers the stress tends to fall on the second syllable: yišt'aġal (he works), etc., whilst amongst older speakers it can fall on the same syllable or on the first: y'ištaġal (he works), etc. The first type is clearly the more sedentary variety (Behnstedt 1997:142-143), and, as was noted above (5.6.2.6.1) the second is more typical of Bedouin dialects." (Pickett 2005: 244).

cit.quote: he is cut, he gets cut

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "Form VII (the n-prefix) derives the passive and also, in the case of some verbs, denotes acquiescence to an action which was precipitated by others, or by a situation, e.g. nṣaraf/yinṣarif lit. ‘to leave’, but in ʿAmmānī (as in the Levant in general) its meaning is similar to British English ‘to buzz off’. There is considerable variation in the imperfect of this Form among ʿAmmānīs." (Al-Wer 2007:11)

"In the speech of the Jordanians, n- prefixed to Form I (both CaCaC and CiCiC) yields as imperfect either yinCaCiC, or yinCaCaC, yinkatib ˜ yinkatab, yinšarib ˜ yinšarab. For some speakers of Palestinian origin, resyllabification occurs, yielding yinCCiC, yinktib, yinšrib. It seems that the (originally) Palestinian yinCCiC is leveled out by the third generation, and that the (originally) Jordanian yinCaCiC ˜ yinCaCaC is undergoing focusing." (Al-Wer 2007:11)
No ex for form VIII
"Forms VII and VIII have bases -inqatil- and -iqtatil- respectively, with regular a>i in unstressed open syllable and elision of i." (Blanc 1970:139)
No example for form VIII

"FORM VII: the imperfect form has the underlying base -inC1aC2iC3- with regular raising of a>i in unstressed open syllable. FORM VIII: the imperfect form has the underlying base -iC1taC2iC3- with regular raising of a>i in unstressed open syllable." (Shawarabah 2012: 242, 244)

cit.quote: he goes somewhere in the early morning when it is still dark

wib:featureValueObservation.note: No example for Form VII
Deduced from examples
No example for Form VIII
No example for Form VIII

"In the imperfect and imperative of themes VII and VIII the vowel of the post-initial syllable may be i. Thus forms like (y)iḥtirim and iḥtirim are freely variant with forms such as (y)iḥtarim and iḥtarim." (Johnstone 1967)
Johnstone (1967) does not differentiate between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna

"In the imperfect and imperative of themes VII and VIII the vowel of the post-initial syllable may be i. Thus forms like (y)iḥtirim and iḥtirim are freely variant with forms such as (y)iḥtarim and iḥtarim." (Johnstone 1967)
Johnstone (1967) does not differentiate between the ʕArab and the Baḥārna

No example for Form VII
As in other varieties of the area, the b- is compulsory in Darfuri Arabic.
The form yištáġal is the exception as it takes the form yiCtaCaC.
deduced from examples
one vestigial verb is nḍaṛṛ "il a été touché par le mal"
two medial weak verbs in VII are attested: yindās "he is trampled", yinzād "he is born"
The vowel in Form VII depends on the vowel of the respective Form I verb; as for Form VIII, there are only a few lexicalized verbs found (Borg 1985:98-99)
There is no form VII.
Stress not specifically mentioned
